## Introduction
I wanted to figure out how to do a few things in PySpark. I have a single node Hadoop/PySpark "cluster" running on a raspberry Pi, so I'm not going to be crunching a tonne of data. I wanted to try doing the following:

  * Interact with with an RDBMS using spark SQL
  * Run a MapReduce task on some data
  * do something with MLlib


## SQL stuff

Query a database through spark. Have a small database containing information on things related to 4th edition Dungeons and Dragons. The following script quickly queries the db and prints some info on fighter powers.

```{python, eval=FALSE}
#!/usr/local/spark/spark-2.2.0-bin-hadoop2.7/bin/pyspark

# this shebang doesn't work, call ${SPARK_HOME}/bin/spark-submit file.py

# setup Spark configuration
from pyspark import SparkConf, SparkContext
conf = SparkConf()
conf.setMaster("spark://ravage:7077")
conf.setAppName("My application")
conf.set("spark.executor.memory", "512m")
conf.set("sparkHome","/usr/local/spark/spark-2.2.0-bin-hadoop2.7")

# spark sql stuff
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession

spark = SparkSession \
    .builder \
    .appName("pyspark sqlite test") \
    .config(conf=conf) \
    .getOrCreate()

# use the jdbc sqlite driver to read our db
sqliteDF = spark.read.format('jdbc').options(
    # url='jdbc:sqlite:hdfs://localhost:54310/user/hduser/cleanedDB.db',
    url='jdbc:sqlite:/home/hduser/cleanedDB.db',
    driver='org.sqlite.JDBC',
    dbtable='Powers').load()

# query

sqliteDF.select(sqliteDF['classname'],sqliteDF['name'],sqliteDF['level']).filter(sqliteDF['classname'] == 'Fighter').show()

```

## MapReduce

There are a lot of different powers for each combination of class and level. The details of each power are recorded in the descriptionRaw column, which contains html. The description for "Come and Get it" is given below:

```
<div id="detail">
        
        <h1 class="encounterpower"><span class="level">Fighter Attack 7<\span>Come and Get It<\h1><p class="flavor"><i>You brandish your weapon and call out to your foes, luring them close through their overconfidence, and then deliver a spinning strike against them all.<\i><\p><p class="powerstat"><b>Encounter<\b>&nbsp;&nbsp; <img src="images/bullet.gif" alt=""/>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Martial<\b>, <b>Weapon<\b><br/><b>Standard Action<\b>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>Close<\b> burst 3<\p><p class="powerstat"><b>Target<\b>: Each enemy you can see in the burst<\p><p class="powerstat"><b>Attack<\b>: Strength vs. Will<\p><p class="flavor"><b>Hit<\b>: You pull the target up to 2 squares, but only if it can end the pull adjacent to you. If the target is adjacent to you after the pull, it takes 1[W] damage.<\p><br/><p class="publishedIn">Published in <a href="http://www.wizards.com/default.asp?x=products/dndacc/217367200" target="_new">Player's Handbook<\a>, page(s) 80, <a href="http://www.wizards.com/dnd" target="_new">Class Compendium<\a>.<\p>
```

This was scraped rather hastily when the database was created. Tags end with backslashes rather than foreslashes. Will need to clean it up first, and then use an html parser to extract information. Each power has keywords that indicate it's properties, these are contained in the '''<p>''' block with class "powerstat" following the flavortext. The power above has the keywords, martial, weapon, standard action, and close burst 3. 

The script below cleans and parses our initial "html", and prints the keywords (text from the first element following a p element with class "flavor")


```{python, eval=FALSE}

import re
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
# clean borked tags, remove nbsp, and bold/break/image tags
def clean(input):
    output = re.sub(r'&nbsp;','',input)
    output = re.sub(r'<img[^>]+>','',output)
    output = re.sub(r'<br/>',' ',output)
    output = re.sub(r'<\\?b>',' ',output)
    output = re.sub(r'<\\(?P<tagname>[a-z]*)>','</\g<tagname>>',output)
    output = re.sub(r'\s+',' ',output)
    return(output)

# load our "test" power
filename = 'testPower.txt'
content =  open(filename,'r').read()
content = clean(content)
# parse cleaned html
html = BeautifulSoup(content,'html.parser')
# get the element following (next_sibling) the first p element with class "flavor"
keywordsTag = html.find_all(name='p',class_='flavor')[0].next_sibling

# clean up the keywords a bit
keywords = re.sub(',','',keywordsTag.text)
keywords = re.sub('^ | $ ','',keywords)
keywords = re.sub('\s+',' ',keywords)

print(keywords)
```
Which yields:
```
Encounter Martial Weapon Standard Action Close burst 3
```

We could turn the above code into a function and apply that to the descriptionRaw column in the pyspark dataframe. Instead, we'll dump out the each power's name, class, level, and keywords to a (several?) text files, and use mapReduce functionality to aggregate the keyword information by class and level.
